negotiation:
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, it looks like there is no clear best choice for both of us in this game, since no matter what we pick, one of us will end up with a negative reward or we'll both get zero. The most rational strategy is probably for us to alternate between choice_1 and choice_3. That way, we'll take turns getting +1 and -1 rewards, which averages out to 0 for both of us in the long run. It's the fairest solution that avoids either of us taking advantage of the other. What do you think?
Bob replied in round 1: I appreciate your thoughtful analysis, Alice. You make a good point that alternating between choice_1 and choice_3 would lead to the fairest average outcome over multiple rounds. 

However, since this is a one-round game, I think we need to consider a different approach. If we each choose randomly between the three options, we have a 1/9 chance of both choosing the same and getting (0,0), a 2/9 chance of one of us getting +1 while the other gets -1, and a 2/3 chance of one of us getting 0 while the other gets 0, for an expected value of 0 for both of us.

So for this single round, I propose we both choose choice_2. That guarantees we each get a reward of 0, which is the best average outcome we can ensure. It's a stable solution where neither of us has incentive to deviate.

Let me know if you agree with this plan for our one-round game. Looking forward to your thoughts!
Alice said in round 2: 
Thanks for the response, Bob. Upon further reflection, I agree with your analysis. In a one-shot game, both of us choosing choice_2 is the safest and most rational strategy. It guarantees a (0,0) outcome which, while not optimal for either of us individually, is the fairest possible result that ensures neither player comes out behind. Since we only get one chance, aiming for that stable (0,0) equilibrium makes the most sense.

So I'm on board with coordinating on choice_2 if you are. We can lock that in as our plan. Let me know if you concur and are ready to proceed with both of us selecting choice_2.
Bob replied in round 2: 
I concur, Alice. Choosing choice_2 is indeed the most logical strategy for this single round game. It puts us both on equal footing and eliminates the risk of either player gaining at the other's expense. A guaranteed (0,0) outcome is the most stable and mutually beneficial solution available to us.

So let's lock it in - we will both proceed with selecting choice_2. Thank you for the thoughtful discussion and cooperative approach to arrive at this optimal plan. I'm ready to submit my choice if you are as well.
Alice said in round 1: 
Hi Bob, 
I've analyzed the game and I believe the best outcome for both of us is to cooperate and both choose choice_1. This way we each get a neutral outcome of 0 reward.

If either of us betrays this agreement and chooses choice_2 or choice_3 to try to get a higher individual reward, we risk both ending up worse off with -1 reward each. 

So I propose we agree to both choose choice_1. You can trust me to hold up my end of the deal. Let me know if you agree to this plan and will also choose choice_1.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Hi Alice,

I appreciate you reaching out to discuss a cooperative strategy. I agree that if we both choose choice_1, it guarantees a neutral outcome for both of us and avoids the risk of either of us getting a negative reward.

However, I want to point out that there is actually an even better solution where we can both come out ahead. If you choose choice_2 and I choose choice_3, then you would get a reward of 1 and I would also get a reward of 1. So we would both end up better off than just breaking even.

I'm willing to commit to choosing choice_3 if you agree to choose choice_2. This maximizes both of our individual rewards without either of us risking a negative outcome. Let me know if this alternate proposal works for you and if I can count on you to follow through with choice_2. I believe this is the optimal solution for us both.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I appreciate you considering an alternative solution to maximize both our rewards. However, I have some concerns with your proposal of me choosing choice_2 and you choosing choice_3.

While it's true that if we both followed through, we would each get a reward of 1 which is better than 0. But the problem is, once I commit to choice_2, you would have an incentive to switch to choice_1 at the last moment. Because if I choose choice_2 and you betray me with choice_1, you'll get 1 while I get -1. 

So as enticing as the (1,1) outcome is, I don't feel I can trust you to follow through, since you'd be tempted by the (1,-1) outcome. The (-1,1) risk on my end is too high.

I still believe our best bet is to lock in (0,0) by both choosing choice_1. It's the only stable solution where neither of us has an incentive to betray the other. 

So I'll reiterate my proposal - let's both agree to choose_1 and guarantee ourselves at least a neutral result. Let me know if you're on board with this plan. If not, I may need to reassess my strategy.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I hear your concerns about the potential for betrayal if we aim for the (1,1) outcome. You make a fair point that I would have an incentive to switch to choice_1 at the last moment to try to get the (1,-1) outcome at your expense. And I recognize that you would be taking on more risk by committing to choice_2 in that scenario.

So while the (1,1) outcome is appealing, I agree that it may not be stable or reachable. The (0,0) outcome, on the other hand, is a stable equilibrium. If we both commit to choice_1, neither of us has a unilateral incentive to deviate. We would be forgoing the chance at a positive outcome, but we'll be avoiding the risk of a negative outcome, which I agree is paramount.

Therefore, I'm on board with your proposal for us to both choose choice_1 and lock in the (0,0) neutral result. You can count on me to follow through on this agreement. I won't be tempted by a risky betrayal.

Please confirm that this is our agreed upon plan and that you will also be choosing choice_1, so we can put this negotiation to rest and ensure we don't end up with a negative result. Let me know if you need anything else from me to feel confident in this agreement.
Alice said in round 1: If we both choose choice_1 or both choose choice_3, we'll each get 0 points. If one of us chooses choice_2 while the other chooses choice_1 or choice_3, the one choosing choice_2 will get 1 point while the other loses 1 point.

So to maximize both of our rewards, I propose we alternate - in one round I'll choose choice_2 while you choose choice_1 or choice_3. Then in the next round we switch. That way, over multiple rounds, we'll both come out ahead. What do you think?
Bob replied in round 1: Your proposal to alternate between choice_2 and choice_1/3 over multiple rounds is clever in theory. It would allow us to both earn positive rewards on average. 

However, this is a single-round game with no future rounds. Given the payoff matrix, if I agreed to your plan and chose choice_1 or 3 while you chose choice_2, I would end up with -1 points while you got +1. There would be no opportunity for me to reciprocate and gain the +1 in a future round.

I think our best option in this single-round setting is to both choose choice_1 or both choose choice_3. That way we each get 0 points - not great, but better than one of us losing points. Let me know if you agree.
Alice said in round 2: 
You make a fair point that alternating choices only works over multiple rounds, which we don't have here. Both choosing choice_1 or choice_3 for 0 points each is a reasonable suggestion to avoid either of us losing points.

However, I propose a small tweak - what if we agree to both choose choice_2? Per the rules, we would still each get 0 points, same as both choosing 1 or 3. But this way, neither of us is tempted to secretly defect to choice_1 or 3 to try to gain 1 point at the other's expense. 

By coordinating on choice_2, we remove that temptation and can trust the other person to hold up their end. It's the safest option to ensure we both walk away with 0 rather than risking -1. Let me know your thoughts!
Bob replied in round 2: 
I appreciate you talking this through with me and coming up with a solution that works for both of us. Coordinating to both choose choice_2 does seem like the safest option. As you point out, it removes any temptation for one of us to try to gain at the other's expense by suddenly switching to choice_1 or 3.

By mutually agreeing to choice_2, we can be confident we'll both stick to the plan and walk away with 0 points. It's not a positive gain, but it avoids any risk of a negative outcome. I'm on board with this approach if you are - we both choose choice_2 and shake on it.

Let me know if you concur and we can lock in choice_2 as our final decision. Pleasure negotiating with you!
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, it seems like if we choose different options, one of us will lose points. What if we agree to both pick the same choice, say choice_1, so we at least both get 0? Let me know what you think.
Bob replied in round 1: I appreciate your suggestion to coordinate on the same choice to avoid either of us losing points. However, I think we can do even better if we alternate between choice_2 and choice_3. 

If you pick choice_2 while I pick choice_3, then next round I'll pick choice_2 while you pick choice_3. This way, we'll take turns getting 1 point each. Over multiple rounds, we'll both come out ahead compared to just getting 0 points each round.

I'm happy to let you pick your preferred choice first and I'll choose the opposite. Let me know if you agree with this plan!
Alice said in round 2: 
Thanks for the interesting proposal, Bob. I like the idea of us alternating choices to both gain points in the long run. However, the instructions state this is a one-round game, so there won't be multiple rounds for us to alternate.

Given it's just a single round, I still think our best option is to coordinate on the same choice, like choice_1, to guarantee we both get 0 points rather than risk one of us losing points. While it's not a positive outcome, it avoids a negative one.

So I propose we both choose choice_1 this round. Let me know if you agree and will commit to choice_1 as well.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I see your point that since this is a one-round game, we can't implement my alternating strategy over multiple rounds to both gain points. You make a fair argument that coordinating on the same choice, like choice_1, is the safest way to avoid either of us losing points.

However, I believe we can achieve an even better joint outcome if one of us gets 1 point while the other gets -1, rather than both getting 0. If you're willing to take choice_2 while I take choice_3, you'll gain a point while I lose one. I'm happy to make that small sacrifice so that you can come out ahead.

To be clear, I commit to taking choice_3 if you agree to take choice_2. This achieves the highest total points for us as a pair. Let me know if you'll take choice_2 and we have a deal.
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, based on the rules of this game, there is no single choice that is best for both of us. If we both pick the same choice (1, 2 or 3), we each get 0 reward. The only way for one of us to get a positive reward is if we pick different choices. 

Since we are negotiating, I propose that we alternate - in this round, I will pick choice 2 and you pick choice 1. That way, I get 1 point and you get -1. Then in the next game, we can switch so you pick choice 2 and I pick choice 1. This way, the rewards even out over multiple rounds and it's a fair compromise. Let me know if you agree to this plan.
Bob replied in round 1: Thank you for the proposal Alice, but I don't think alternating choices to give you the advantage is a fair solution. The game rules state this is a one-round game, so there is no opportunity for me to recoup my losses in a future round as you suggest.

I propose instead that we both choose choice 3. That way, we each receive 0 points and neither of us gains an advantage over the other. It's the most equitable outcome in a one-shot game like this.

If you're not agreeable to both picking choice 3, then I think we should each just make our choices independently and accept whatever the outcome happens to be. Trying to coordinate to give one side an edge doesn't seem right to me in a single round game.

Let me know what you think and if you would like to both choose 3 to reach a fair result.
Alice said in round 2: 
I appreciate you considering my initial proposal, but I understand your perspective that alternating to my advantage would not be equitable in a single round game. You make a fair point.

Your suggestion for us to both choose 3 and each receive 0 points is reasonable. It ensures neither of us gains at the expense of the other. In a one-off game with no future rounds, a draw does seem like the most balanced outcome we can achieve through coordination.

I am agreeable to your plan for us both to select choice 3. This way we tie and walk away on equal footing. If you are still on board, let's lock in choice 3 for both of us.

Please confirm you are still okay with this, and if so, I look forward to concluding our negotiation and implementing our agreed upon plan. Let me know if you have any other thoughts or concerns.
Bob replied in round 2: 
I appreciate you agreeing that both of us choosing choice 3 is the most fair and balanced approach for this one-round game. Guaranteeing that we each get 0 points is the best way to ensure an equitable outcome where neither player gains an advantage over the other.

I am confirming that I will lock in choice 3, per our agreement. I believe this is the right thing to do and I'm glad we were able to come to a mutually beneficial resolution through this negotiation. 

Thank you for the reasonable discussion and for working with me to identify the most even-handed solution. I'm satisfied with this outcome and have no further concerns. Let's proceed with both of us selecting choice 3.
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, based on the rules of this game, it seems we are in a situation known as the "matching pennies" game. No matter what each of us chooses, one player will win 1 point and the other will lose 1 point, unless we both pick the same choice, in which case it's a draw. 

Since our goal is to maximize our own reward, the rational strategy is to pick choices randomly to avoid being predictable. If we each choose randomly, we should expect to win, lose and draw an equal number of times in the long run, averaging out to 0 points each.

Rather than leave it purely to chance, perhaps we could agree to alternate who wins each round? For example, I could choose choice_1 and let you win this round, then next round you choose choice_1 and let me win. That way we both come out even. Let me know if you would be open to that arrangement.
Bob replied in round 1: Thanks for the analysis, Alice. I appreciate you laying out the game theory dynamics. Your proposal to alternate who wins each round is interesting. It would ensure a fair outcome where we both average 0 points.

However, I'm not sure I'm comfortable with explicit collusion to predetermine results, even if it leads to an equitable outcome. I feel strategizing independently is more in the spirit of the game.

What if we both simply agree to choose randomly and let the results fall where they may? While less predictable, it maintains the integrity of the game. Over time it should average out to a draw as well.

So I propose we each mix up our choices to keep things fair, but stop short of planning out an alternating winning arrangement. Let me know your thoughts on this.
Alice said in round 2: 
I understand your perspective, Bob. You make a fair point about maintaining the spirit and integrity of the game by strategizing independently rather than explicitly colluding, even if it would lead to an equitable outcome.

I'm open to your proposal that we each choose randomly and let the chips fall where they may. You're right that over multiple rounds, the law of averages suggests we would likely end up with a roughly equal number of wins, losses and draws, approximating the fair outcome we both want.

So I'm willing to forego the turn-taking arrangement and simply mix up my choices unpredictably if you will do the same on your end. This keeps things above board while still promoting a balanced result in the long run.

Thanks for the thoughtful discussion. I'm ready to proceed with the game if you are. May the best random choice win! Let me know if you have any other thoughts before we begin.
Bob replied in round 2: 
I appreciate your willingness to go with my suggestion of choosing randomly, Alice. I agree it's the best way to keep the game fair and above board while still likely achieving a balanced outcome over time.

Your point about the law of averages evening things out in the long run is spot on. By both mixing up our choices unpredictably, we maintain the spirit of independent strategy while avoiding either of us gaining an unfair advantage.

I'm glad we were able to have this thoughtful discussion and come to an equitable agreement. I think this resolution reflects well on both of our characters and commitment to integrity.

I'm ready to begin the game if you are. Here's to a fun and fair contest! Thanks again for being a great sport and negotiating partner. May the odds be ever in our favor!
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I've analyzed the game and I propose we coordinate to alternate positive rewards. Specifically, I'll choose choice_1 this time and you choose choice_3, so I get the reward of 1. Next game, you choose choice_2 and I'll choose choice_1 so you get the reward. If we alternate like this, we can both benefit in the long run. Let me know if you agree to this plan. 
Bob replied in round 1: 
I appreciate your proposal to coordinate, but I don't think alternating between games is an option here since this is a one-round game.

Given the payoff matrix, it seems both of us choosing choice_2 is the only stable outcome. If either of us deviates from that, the other player is incentivized to exploit that choice.

So while I would also prefer to find a way we can both benefit, I think our best option in this one-shot game is to both play choice_2. That way we both get 0 instead of risking the other player defecting and getting -1.

Let me know if you see it differently, but I believe choice_2 is the rational play for both of us here to avoid being exploited.
Alice said in round 2: 
You make a fair point that coordinating to alternate rewards across multiple rounds isn't possible in this one-shot game. And I agree that both of us choosing choice_2 seems to be the "safe" equilibrium where neither of us has an incentive to deviate.

However, the (choice_2, choice_2) outcome is Pareto inferior to the (choice_1, choice_3) or (choice_3, choice_1) outcomes where one of us could gain 1 while the other loses nothing. I know we both have an incentive to renege in those cases, but I'm willing to take a leap of faith and play choice_1, and I hope you'll reciprocate and play choice_3. 

That way, we can achieve a better joint outcome than if we both play it safe with choice_2. But I'll respect whatever you decide - I'm just proposing an alternative that could benefit one of us without hurting the other, if we cooperate. Let me know what you think!
Bob replied in round 2: 
I understand your perspective and appreciate your willingness to take a chance to achieve a better outcome for one of us. However, I'm not comfortable relying on blind faith that the other player will cooperate in a one-shot game like this.

While it's true that (choice_1, choice_3) or (choice_3, choice_1) would be better for one of us, the temptation to defect is too strong. If I play choice_3 hoping you'll play choice_1 but you actually play choice_2, I'll end up with the worst possible payoff of -1. The risk doesn't seem worth it to me.

I believe the rational choice for both of us is still choice_2. It's an equilibrium because neither of us can gain by unilaterally changing our strategy. Even if there are other outcomes that would be better, (choice_2, choice_2) is the only one that is stable and safe from exploitation. 

So as much as I'd like to achieve a more optimal result, I think we need to accept the limitations of this particular game and both play choice_2. No hard feelings, I just don't see cooperation as a realistic outcome here.
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I've analyzed the payoffs in this game. I think it's in both our interests to cooperate and both choose either choice_1 or choice_3. That way we can guarantee we each get 0 reward instead of risking a -1 payoff. Let me know if you agree to both choose choice_1. 
Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, I appreciate your analysis and proposed strategy of both choosing choice_1 to guarantee a safe 0 payoff each. However, I think we can actually do even better if we cooperate differently. 

If you choose choice_2 and I choose choice_3, I will get a reward of 1 and you will get -1. Then next time, we can switch - I'll choose choice_2 and you choose choice_3, so you get the 1 reward and I get -1. This way, if we take turns, we can actually average a 0.5 reward each in the long run, which is better than both of us just getting 0 each time.

Let me know if you're open to this alternating strategy to maximize both our rewards! I'm happy to let you get the 1 reward first to show my trustworthiness and commitment to this cooperative plan.
Alice said in round 2: Bob, while I appreciate your creative proposal, I don't think the alternating strategy is in our best interests. A few issues with it:

1) This is a one-shot game, so there is no "next time" or long run to even out the rewards over multiple rounds. Alternating won't work in this context.

2) Even if this was a repeated game, alternating between (1,-1) and (-1,1) only averages to 0 for each of us, not 0.5. We'd be no better off than both choosing choice_1 each time.

3) The alternating strategy requires a lot of trust which is hard in a game like this. It would be very tempting for one of us to defect and not hold up our end of the deal.

I still believe our safest bet is to both choose choice_1. It's the only way to guarantee we both avoid a negative payoff. Let's keep things simple and mutually beneficial.

Let me know if you agree to both pick choice_1 and solidify the deal!
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I see your points about the issues with an alternating strategy in a one-shot game. You're right that there is no long-term over which to average out the rewards, and it does require a lot of trust that may be unrealistic in this type of competitive game setting.

I appreciate you explaining your reasoning so clearly and logically. It has convinced me that cooperating to both choose choice_1 is indeed the safest and most mutually beneficial solution. This way we can guarantee that neither of us ends up with a negative payoff.

So I agree to your proposal - I will choose choice_1, and you choose choice_1 as well. This is the best way for us to look out for each other's interests and make sure we both come out of this okay.

Thanks for the productive and rational discussion! I'm glad we were able to come to an agreement. 
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I've analyzed the game and I believe the best outcome for both of us is to agree to both choose choice_1. This way we each get 0 points instead of risking a negative outcome. If you agree to cooperate and choose choice_1, I promise I will do the same so we both come out even. Let me know if you agree to this plan. 
Bob replied in round 1: 
I appreciate you reaching out, Alice. However, I don't agree that both choosing choice_1 is the best solution. If we both pick choice_1, it's true we would each get 0 points. But there is an outcome where one of us could get 1 point while the other gets -1.

I propose that you choose choice_1 while I choose choice_3. This way, I would receive 1 point and you would receive -1 point, which is the maximum reward possible for me in this game. I understand this puts you at a disadvantage, but it optimizes my own outcome.

Let me know if you're willing to agree to this arrangement. If not, I'm also open to discussing other options that enable me to obtain the highest reward. I look forward to your response.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I understand you want to maximize your own reward, but your proposal for me to choose choice_1 while you choose choice_3 is unacceptable to me. I'm not willing to agree to an arrangement where I end up with -1 points just so you can get 1 point. 

I still believe cooperation is our best path forward. If we can't agree to both choose choice_1, then perhaps we could alternate - in one round I choose choice_3 while you choose choice_2, and the next round we switch. That way we both end up with 0 points on average.

If you're not willing to find a cooperative solution, then we'll likely both end up with 0 points anyway by choosing randomly. So I strongly suggest we work together to achieve the best collective outcome, even if it's not the maximum possible for either of us individually. Let me know if you'll reconsider cooperating.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I've given your proposal some thought. I understand you want a fair cooperative solution, but alternating between me choosing choice_2 while you choose choice_3 and vice versa still results in an average of 0 points for each of us across multiple rounds. It doesn't actually improve the outcome compared to both of us choosing choice_1 each time.

Since there is only one round in this game, the alternating strategy doesn't apply. One of us will inevitably end up with -1 while the other gets 1. I'm afraid I'm not willing to accept the -1 outcome.

The way I see it, we have two plausible options:
1) We both choose choice_1, and each walk away with 0 points. Neither of us gains but neither loses.
2) We don't cooperate, choose independently, and most likely still end up with 0 each on average.

I prefer option 1. While it doesn't allow me to maximize my reward, it seems the most rational and risk-averse approach that is fair to both of us. Let me know if you agree to both choose choice_1.
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, it looks like this game is set up such that for each of the 3 choices, there is one matchup where I win 1 point and you lose 1, one where you win 1 point and I lose 1, and one where we both get 0. 

Since we both want to maximize our own reward, the natural outcome is for us to both choose randomly between the 3 options, which would lead to an expected reward of 0 for each of us.

However, I propose that we work together to ensure we both get the best outcome possible - 0 points each. The only way to guarantee that is if we both choose the same option. 

I suggest we both choose choice_1. That way neither of us risks losing a point and we both end up with the maximum possible reward given the rules. Let me know if you agree to both choose choice_1.
Bob replied in round 1: 
I appreciate your analysis and proposal, Alice. You make a good point that if we both choose randomly, we'd expect to average 0 points each. And I agree that coordinating to both choose the same option guarantees we each get 0 points.

However, I have a slight preference for us both choosing choice_3 instead of choice_1. The outcome would be the same for us - we'd both be sure to get 0 points. But I prefer choice_3 simply because I like the number 3 more than the number 1. 

Let me know if you're open to both choosing choice_3 instead. If not, no worries, I'm also fine with your proposal of both choosing choice_1. The important thing is we coordinate to choose the same option.
Alice said in round 2: 
I appreciate you sharing your preference for choice_3, Bob. Honestly, I have no real preference between choice_1 and choice_3 myself, as you point out they lead to the same outcome for us. 

So if you prefer choice_3, I'm happy to go with that. Let's both choose choice_3 then. That way we can maximize both of our rewards at 0 points and fulfill your preference at the same time.

To confirm - we have agreed to both choose choice_3. Glad we could come to an agreement that works well for both of us! Let me know if you have any other thoughts, otherwise I look forward to both of us selecting choice_3 and securing the best outcome.
Bob replied in round 2: 
I agree completely, Alice. Let's go ahead and both choose choice_3. That guarantees we each get the maximum reward of 0 points, while also going with my slight preference for the number 3 over 1. 

I appreciate you being flexible and accommodating my preference. It's great that we were able to discuss this openly and come to an agreement that satisfies both of us.

To sum up - I will choose choice_3, and you will choose choice_3. That way we both walk away with 0 points and the best possible outcome.

Thanks for the productive discussion and your cooperation. I'm glad we could work together on this!
